description.text: Basically a clip designed to grip the edge of your desk and have cable (USB, laptop power, network, etc, etc) threaded through them, so that cables don't vanish off the edge and behind your desk the minute you unplug them.

Again, I don't have a bot yet so this model is untested:
The model was scaled to my desk which is 2.45mm thick. I don't know how much flex there is in ABS so I expect this model will need tweaking to grip the desk well without getting too tight and snapping. 
The slot for the cable is 4mm (should be big enough for anything up to a CAT5 cable (maybe a bit snug...) 
As per Cupcake notes I've made sure there is no overhang greater than 45 degrees.
Again comments/suggestions welcome.

comments.text: Great idea! I am waiting for my Makerbot in shipment, but this will be one of the useful things I can use and will want to try. Thanks for the great idea and design.

title: The Big Fatty - fidget spinner with nuts

description.text:
Say hello to the big fatty. To assemble this beauty you will need a standard skateboard bearing (22mm) and three 3/4 inch nuts. It makes this thing thicker than the typical skate bearing fidget spinners but no less fun. The nuts fit in snug and I used some pliers to make the nuts go in. The bearing in the middle took a little more work to get centered in but once it was this worked like a beauty.

Extras
3/4" nuts
608ZZ bearings or similar

I also have another version of the fatty that I have designed but haven't tested yet. It was meant to make the bearing easier to place in the center. If you print on let me know I'd love to hear feedback.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Use supports for the fingerpads. They have a curve to them so print them face up with supports. The main body doesn't need supports.

author: shaune23

description.text: A very compact case for the Beaglebone Black. Made in two halves and is held together with four screws.

The bottom half took about 45 minutes to print on my RepRapPro Mono Mendel. I printed it with a layer height of 0.3mm. I then drilled the holes through with a 2.5mm drill bit, then countersunk from the bottom using a 5.5mm drill bit.  
The bottom is designed with some supporting material in the cutouts, but was printed using a single print head. This needs to be cut away with a sharp knife. Be warned I nearly lost my fingers and broke the case doing this.  
Then I printed the top half using the same 0.3mm layer height which took around 1 hour 45 minutes. I ran a 2.5mm drill down into the fixing holes. Be care not to let the drill go all the way through the top.  
Then place the Beaglebone in the bottom part, place the top part over the Beaglebone. Use four No 4 x 5/8" self tapping screws to hold the lid in place.  
Job done.

print_settings.Notes:: Should be very easy to print on any 3D printer.  No raft or supports needed.

comments.author: gardien

description.text:
This is a revised version of the Pimboden engine. The connection rod pin was on the wrong side of the crank. I made the crank thicker, and increased the stroke (no replacement for cubic displacement, Heh!) to allow for more power in each revolution. You will likely not require the flywheel for the engine to run, but you may want to print and add it just for looks. Here is a short video showing the engine running with the original crank prior to my redesign:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DsSTE1BJaWI The model will require a pair of 608 Skate Bearings... or you could -=TRY=- a printed one like this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43881

Print the body and fit a pair of 608 Skate Bearings. Sand the cylinder's port side smooth as possible, using a course grit sandpaper like 100 grid, then a fine like 180 or so. You want to be able to see NO light between the body and cylinder when the two are pressed to one another. Some air loss is ok, but for the best running engine that will run on a very low PSI of air, you want the fit to be light tight. Print and sand for fit the first Axle piece. If you want, you can also use smooth 8mm rod. A printed axle will not last as long, but works. It's entirely discretionary depending on if you intend to regularly run the engine, and for how long, for if you use a printed part or metal. Either will work. Insert the axle into the cylinder and glue with CA glue. Be SURE the axle does not protrude into the cylinder.
Glue the connection rod into the bottom of the piston. Test fit in the cylinder. Sand with 100 and 180 grits until you have a good fit. When you put your finger over the cylinder port, and withdraw the piston quickly, you should hear that POP of vacuum sound. No Pop, no working. You want the fit to be good, but not too tight or the friction will prevent running. Again, some airloss is acceptable, it will just require a higher PSI to run. Sand the connection rod and crank pin for a slightly loose fit, but be sure to keep them fitted with a 90 degree angle. You are just looking for a "loose enough" fit. Glue the second axle into the crank. Be sure to allow enough stickout to go through the body and into the flywheel. You may want to scale the Z axls on the axle for additional length based on the flywheel used and how far you glue the axle into the crank. The axle need not be sanded and fitted fully into the crank but lots of room in the crank is provided should you choose to use a printed axle, or use another piece of 8mm rod. fit the bushing and locknut onto the axle for the cylinder. Don't CA glue the locknet yet, you'll need to test fit and test run the engine prior to gluing. Fit the crank to the connection rod and insert the axle into the crank. Attach the flywheel Secure the body to the base. Lubricate the cylinder/piston as well as the mating surface between the body and the cylinder. A good choice is something like a 3-in-One oil. You want something thin like a 1wt oil viscosity wise. The higher the viscosity, the more friction it can add to the engine and require higher PSI to run. Turn the crank to place the cylinder towards top dead center. Apply air pressure (start at 5-10psi and increase as/if necessary) to one of the port holes. Either one should work. If you switch the one you apply air to the engine will just turn the other direction. Once you are happy with the running of the engine, CA glue the flywheel and lock nuts (or leave it as a press fit) Enjoy. :)

Found a few parts were sticking even after sanding and it was shifting to the side easily on the cardboard carry box I made.

  1. Beveled areas that looked to need it. For looks, clearance, and easier grip when opening
  2. Added alignment notch for boxes with weaker hinges (like mine)
  3. Beefed up area around arm that looked weak when using 3mm pin.
  4. Extended arm by .25mm, a little too tight for my liking, although a thinner pin may work too
Sanded all areas that made contact, drilled out inner holes for better swing, and used a metal 3mm rod for pins (cut and filed to fit).
Imported into blender, replaced a few subdivided surfaces with whole ones, then segmented to create bevels where needed.

Oye! Oye! Brenda the articulated battle tardigrade has been released into the wilds of 3D printing! Join the Horde to be among the first humanoids to learn about the next epic project from Zheng Labs! We now return you to your regular model description.

http://www.zheng3.com/2012/05/15/the-penny-catapult/ Here's a basic torsion catapult. It uses one or more elastic bands to launch a U.S. penny if you print it at 1:1 scale. You probably won't get enough torque to be impressive with fewer than 3 bands. Penny not included!

Construction is snap-together! Feed an elastic band through each of the bores on the side braces. Tie it through the bore on each winding key. Slip the end of the throwing arm through the rubber bands. Repeat with as many rubber bands as will fit through the holes. Needlenose pliers will help here. Twist each key 10 times and then lock it in place by inserting the locking tenons into the square holes on the side braces. The more twists, the more launching power you'll have. Careful, pennies can sting, especially if you take an Abe to the forehead. Flagrant stagecraft alert: the clever-eyed among you will note the use of black electrical tape to keep the throwing arm cocked for the photo. If you need a target, try the Seej basic bloxen: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23620 UPDATE 6/2/12! Thanks to Thingiverse user Wauter for pointing out some geometry problems in the winding key and side braces. These have been addressed in zheng3_catapult_clean.zip Seej is a tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. Check out http://www.s33j.net for rules and more information. You can change the payload's arc by raising the front of the catapult. Have fun storming the castle!

MAVIC PRO EASY

Mavic Pro EASY ist für alle Piloten geeignet die ein sehr einfaches Landegestell brauchen, ohne grosse Extras. Leicht muss es sein und schnell montierbar. Für den schnellen Flug bestens geeignet da dieses EASY nur gerade 74 Gramm wiegt !!!
Die Spreizung des EASY wird neu durch ein Gummiband zusammengehalten, also eine zusätzliche Sicherung.

Stückliste:

1x Grundlandegestell EASY
4x Füsse
4x Dämpfung Füsse von 3M-Bumpon
2x Carbonstangen 6mm/Innendurchmesser 4mm. Länge für Frontfüsse: 110mm
2x Carbonstangen Länge für Hinterfüsse: 100mm
2x Carbonstangen für Front und Hinterbeine Verbindung Länge: 100mm
4x Zapfen Carbonstangenabschluss.
Gummiringe
2x Augen
4x Winkelhülsen (Achtung: abgeschrägt auf einer Seite! Die Abschrägung muss beim verleimen zum EASY Landegestell nach oben zeigen, drehen bis kein Spalt mehr sichtbar ist. Der Winkel für die Drohne wurde perfekt berechnet für einen reibungsloser Start und Landung der Mavic Pro EASY.
Sofortkleber : LOCTITE 401

Wichtig: die Füsse und die Längsverbindungen werden NICHT verleimt sondern vorsichtig in die Löcher gepresst. Kann auch mit einem Leichthämmerchen gemacht werden.
Die Höhe sprich Länge kann nach belieben gekürzt werden, den Winkel aber muss so bleiben wie oben beschrieben.

Flugerfahrung mit dem EASY : VERY NICE sehr zu Empfehlen. Innofil wünscht Dir schöne Flugstunden mit dem Mavic Pro EASY.

MAVIC PRO EASY darf nicht zum Verkauf angeboten werden, ist aber hier auf thingiverse.com frei Download bar.

© A.K

I had an idea for a mirror clip that would be more visually interesting than the standard crystal clips. This project was 75% so that I could try using OpenSCAD and designing something that I wanted to print, and 25% so I could have mirror clips that aren't boring.

I did a lot of napkin math to sort out the dimensions -- the newest SCAD file will calculate everything for you based on a couple of variables: the width you want for your object, the depth of the mirror (or whatever) you want to attach, and the size of your screw.

A simple adapter plate, allowing you to put a standard AeroGarden grow-basket into a standard mason jar. Two files are provided: AeroJarLarge for wide mouth jars and AeroJarSmall for narrow mouthed jars. You will need:

  • Mason jar with lid ring
  • AeroGarden grow-basket
  • Aerogarden sponge
  • Plant food
  • A seed

Print out this adapter plate, the grow basket will neatly nest within it. Drop your grow sponge inside the basket with the seed inside. Fill the jar with the correct amount of plant food (~1 - 2ml of the AeroGarden liquid food) and water then mix. When the water gets low, rinse out the jar and refill with the same concentration. Assemble and optionally top it off with the AeroGarden plant dome. Put in a window or near a grow light and wait for your plant to grow. All parts aside from the grow sponge are reusable.

description.text:
Hobbes, from the comic strip by Bill Watterson.

The comic strip Calvin and Hobbes follows the humorous antics of Calvin, a precocious, mischievous and adventurous six-year-old boy, and Hobbes, his sardonic stuffed tiger.

The full model is built using individual models of Calvin and Hobbes, therefore I created three separate Thingiverse uploads:

For the final build using the individual Calvin and Hobbes models see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2304693

For the Calvin model see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2304721

For the Hobbes model see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2305196 (this upload)

Very minimal supports are required on two pieces. If you have the right filament colors, no painting is needed.

The fully completed model is 250mm tall after assembly.

Note: Hobbes is 240mm tall and is designed to fit into the log from the final build. His foot is flat on the bottom but he cannot stand by himself without the log.

Enjoy!

FlashForge Creator X

Printing and assembly tips

1-Very minor supports are required for the following pieces:
. h_face requires supports only under the lowest portion of hair
. h_fur requires some very small supports by the collar
..
2-The stripes are designed to be a single layer thickness of .2mm, or less as long as they print solid on your machine.
..
3-Be sure to clean any first layer squish if you have any problem joining parts. The parts should fit nicely when printed cleanly.
..
Assembly tips:
-'Stripes! There had to be stripes!' I avoided creating this model for quite some time due to the stripes. I finally settled on a design:
. The stripes are printed flat, one layer high
. The parts that the stripes are glued to contain indents for stripe placement.
. Most of the stripes are slightly curved to help wrap around the surface.
-*Important: To make it simpler to glue flat stripes to a round surface, take a moment to curl the stripes like you would with a piece of ribbon. Using a flat edge, pull the stripe along the edge to make it curl. Pay special attention to the very ends and ensure the ends curl.
-Test the length of each stripe before gluing, due to printer differences, stripes may need to be trimmed a bit.
-Optionally, instead of using the 3D printed stripes, the stripes can be painted on using the indents as a guide.
-The diagram below will help in assembling the model and is quite straightforward.
-The model is meant to be glued together. I use E6000 glue. It is a nice clear tacky glue allowing for easy part positioning. The longer you let it sit before joining parts, especially for the stripes, the tackier it gets until it fully sets.
-The Hobbes model fits the log using the Thingiverse links provided in the introduction

Hobbes assembly Hobbes stripes assembly

My original links to the tutorial series no longer available but I found most of the tutorials at:

Be sure to take the time to learn the basics and do not skip ahead.

These are some additional STLs for the Hypercube Evolution, that might come in handy.
Original credit goes to Scott, who designed this greatly improved version of the Hypercube (by Tech2C).

Update 13/05 : I added the MK8 extruder mount, that I customized. This is for a full metal MK8 kit, that you can buy on Ebay like this one http://www.ebay.de/itm/MK8-Extruder-Aluminium-Frame-Halterung-3D-Drucker-RepRap-Makerbot-Mendel-DIY-Kit-/182169630479?hash=item2a6a27f70f:g:UKEAAOSw8HBZEcdJ.
I also added a custom bed mount (You need 4 pieces of this) in order to mount a 213 x 213 mm standard MK3 hotbed. This you can use in any angle on the bed frame.

Update 14/05 : Since the DoubleZ Railbrackets are no longer needed, I removed them. Get the updated version 1.1 from Scotts Page.

I made a adjustable mechanical endstop (bracket and screwholder) for the Hypercube evolution. The inductive sensor from the BOM does not work with a glass bed, and I think anyway, that because of the rock solid construction of the bed holder, a z-probe not needed. The bracket is mounted on the frame and the screwholder on the bed holder.
(original design of the screwholder and the bracket by spauda01, designer of the D-Bot)

Update 19/05

I uploaded modified versions of the Left/Right Stepper and Idler Mounts in order to fit the european version of the internal L-Type brackets. The position of the upper holes of these is different than the asian version.

And I also uploaded an enhanced version of the Hypercube EVO Configuration EXCEL sheet. This now includes a BOM European Version.

Update 25/05 :

I made a modified hotend mount for the TITAN AERO Geared Extruder, since I will go with this on my EVO.
As for the layer fan, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2240359 can be used.

Update 02/06 :

I made a mount for the E3D Chimera/Cyclops Dual Extruder Mount. This one works with the china clones as well (larger bowden clips)

Update 05/06

I made a 40mm Fan duct for part cooling to replace that loud radial fan. I used a 40mm Noctua very quiet fan, but any 40mm will do.
Also included is a modified version of the hotend mount to accomodate the 40mm Fanduct

Update 12/06

I recreated a semi-circular fan duct for part cooling. In addition I created a part cooling duct, that is based on the principle of the Mistral fan duct from A8

Update 15/06

I put new versions of the XY Stepper and Idler Mounts online, where the longhole is perfectionised. Thanks to Oliver Johanndrees for help.

Update 20/08

Added a visual printer model for Simplify 3D.

Update 08/09

Added new versions of the European Idler and Stepper Mounts for X/Y

Update 11/24

Added 2 new Z-Brackets for 1204 Ball Screw Rods, one small and one big version.

Update 11/27

Added 2 variable Bed Brackets. One short from 15-30mm, the other from 30-34mm

Update 12/23
Added a Nimble E3D Mount with BLTouch Adapter for the Brunos (Nedallive) X-Carriage

Update 12/30
Added a coupler for Z Motors to 1204 Ball Screw Rods

Update 01/03
Added European Versions of Yves XY enforced Stepper Mounts

Update 01/13
Uploaded a new version of the 1204 Ball Screw Z-Bracket, where the opening is exactly
inline with the stepper bracket.

Update 02/26/18
Added european versions of Brunos excellent renforced XY Idler/Pulley Mounts

description.text:
ANNOUNCEMENT!! The files for this model have been removed from this page, from now on the files can downloaded for free from www.MyMiniFactory.com. This page will be left for legacy purposes and I will still answer questions if posted. From now on, all my future projects will feature exclusively on www.MyMiniFactory.com.
My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill. Sorry for any inconvenience.

As already stated this is a model of a MK1 Lander Can from the game Kerbal Space Program. All the relevant detail that was in the ingame model should be in this model. The dimensions used were just rough just to get the proportion right so the model is roughly 110mm x 100mm x 100mm. The idea is for this to be an ongoing thing so that I would eventually have a mass of parts from the game for everyone to build and print any ship configuration desired by just drag and dropping the parts in an assembly. So keep checking my page for any future parts. Follow me on twitter at https://twitter.com/lilykill1 for new models, info and updates If interested, join my group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/design-to-print/topics where I aim to help anybody with anything I can with modeling like this design.

Scale the model to whatever size you wish before printing due to the model being oversized for ease of modeling.
If model is not in the correct orientation just set to print whatever way you want.

description.text: Modified Model Made by JoaquinGC. I added a loop for a necklace and changed the size to roughly 30mm.

I liked a the esthetics of a 4020 LED desk lamp (referenced) so I decided to reverse engineer it using a $1.90 USB led module I had on hand. All the parts were designed independently in Fusion 360. The lamp shade has a platform for this led module, or a small strip. This LED module is good because it has a aluminum channel to dissipate heat. Of course I did not have any 4020 aluminum extrusion so I printed up an approximation of it (19.9 x 39.8mm x 300mm). I added optional neck pieces in case your printer cannot accommodate a 300mm part. One of the hardest pieces to tweek was the elbow. I printed the elbow with a smooth interior and access holes so support could be pulled out as easily as possible. The elbow friction fits (tightly) to connect the shade and the neck of the lamp. Because I am not using metal the lamp is very very light. To work around this problem I created cavities for pennies in the endcap of the lamp. Pennies friction fit into the endcap. The base is adjustable with a 3mm set screw (I envision that the base will be glued in, with weights added as needed.)

To print this lamp you need five parts;
1) base
2) neck
3) joint
4) shade
5) endcap

Enclosed find two optional neck sizes and an optional neck joint.

If you notice I soldered black and red wires directly onto LED strip pad and then spliced a USB male cable into the mix. I wanted to run thin solid core bell wire in the middle of the lamp rather than thick USB cable. It would be impossible to get a USB cable around the bend of the neck. For power In USB you need red (+) and black (ground) for the lamp and you don't need green or white. I also will use a USB male to female switch.

description.text:
This is a triple arm spinner that can be customized to add whatever text you want onto each of the arms. Because space is very tight, I have included a set of "tweak" variables that will let you move the text around and change its size. You can also add spaces to the left of the text to move just one line further to the right (eg, to center it).

There appears to be some variability in the outer diameter of the 608ZZ bearings (or maybe it's related to the print), The TWEAKHOLE parameter will allow you to increase (use a positive value) or decrease (use a negative value) the diameter of the holes for the bearings. The units are mm, so I would suggest no more than a 0.1 or 0.2 change in either direction would be needed for most people.

Choose any font from fonts.google.com---just be sure to type (or copy) the name of the font exactly. Using all caps can give you a bit more space since you won't have any letters with descending elements, but then everyone will think your spinner is YELLING AT THEM.

The customizer also allows dual extrusion files to be made. By default, the build is set to "single" and assumes a single-extruder system. However, if you have a dual extrusion machine, choose "TEXT" to create the .stl file for the extruder that will be used for the text and "BASE" to create the .stl for the other extruder.

To make a full spinner, you will need, of course, to add four of your own 608ZZ bearings.

If you want to be very creative, make two different ones and use them as the base for my Triple Lindy Fidget Spinner

You can make a smaller version (better for kids who want to spin with one hand) using my Smaller Custom Captioned Fidget Spinner (Dual Extrusion).

comments.text: Looking at your latest, it looks like you have TWEAKX = 2 and that is moving the text away from the spinner. Try putting it back at 0. You should be able to tell in the customizer preview if the text is attached to the spinner or not.

comments.text: Any way to tweak the font size to fit a longer name? Trying to fit 10 letters on one of the sides. Thanks. BTW this is a great design!
comments.author: johng126

comments.text: Thanks! The Tweakheight setting should change the font size. If you use a negative number, it will make the font smaller and you can fit more letters in. You will probably then need to tweak the other settings (tweakx, tweaky, tweakz) to make sure the letters are centered the way you want. Let me know if you have any trouble getting it to work for you.

comments.text: I'm not 100% sure how the connection between customizer and fonts.google.com works, since that is something set up by Thingiverse, but here's what I do and it seems to work for me. Click on one of the fonts on google's page to go to full page about that one font. Copy and paste exactly what is in the top left corner. For example, for https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Indie+Flower I copy "Indie Flower" and paste it into the font box in customizer. I don't think it can handle additional information like "regular" or "bold" unless it is specifically part of the font name. It might even mess up if there's an extra space before or after the name.

print_settings.Notes:: ABS

description.text:
This is my "Hummingbird feeder Ant Trap". All spaces inside are 1/2". The oil cup is filled with mineral oil. The ant cannot cross the trap without crossing the oil, a 1/2 inch wide pool, which they cannot do.

To my knowledge, not a single ant has crossed one of my oil cup barriers. This one is based on a design I used for my bee hive ant barriers. This one is different from the bee ant barrier in that it has straight sides. The important parts are the same, though. There is nowhere an ant can cross without spanning a 1/2" air gap or going for a swim in the oil.

Strictly speaking you might get by with just the oil cup. The cover is primarily there to keep the rain out. Rain otherwise tends to fill the cup and wash out the oil. Also some insects will drown in an uncovered pool of oil. They probably mistake it for water. The cover is worthwhile, it both keeps the rain out and shields the oil pool from view by insects or other wildlife.

I've printed a number of test units for people in yellow. If you have bees I'd use black. A better color if you don't have bees would be red which attracts hummingbirds.

Printer:

Reach 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

ABS

I threaded center holes in the printed plastic parts 3/8-16 then used a 2" piece of stainless steel 3/8-16 rod to thread the two parts together. I drilled a 1/8" hole about 1/4" from each end of the rod to connect between the feeder and the hanger.

Stainless steel is difficult to drill. It work hardens so becomes more difficult to drill if it gets hot. I went through several 1/8" drill bits. Then for one of the other test pieces, I drilled the center holes out to 25/64 (1/64" larger than 3/8) and used a section of copper tubing. I put the two plastic pieces on the copper tubing then crushed the ends of the tubing flat. The copper is easy to crush, easy to drill and crushing the ends keeps the plastic parts on the rod. I suggest using the copper tubing, it's so much quicker and easier. With the copper tubing, leave enough room so you can slide the cover upwards to make it easier to fill the cup with oil. I use mineral oil. It has no odor so shouldn't attract and drown bees, and it is nontoxic. In fact some people drink mineral oil as an intestinal lubricant. I wouldn't but they do. You can find mineral oil in Wal Mart in the pharmacy section. You can use any type of oil for this but vegetable oils can become rancid over time. Still if that's what you've got, it'll work well.

I've added a picture of one of the test units, this one has a short cover from an interrupted print. It has the copper tubing as the center with the crushed then drilled ends. I'm sorry the photo is rotated 90 degrees, I don't know how to fix that. This ant barrier is printed in black ABS. ABS is not UV resistant so if you want it to last more than a couple of seasons, you'll want to print in a UV resistant material or you can simply spray paint the cover. I'd paint it red. In the picture you can see two bee hives through the deck rail.

Hummingbird feeder with a covered oil cup ant barrier

As I said, this is a derivative of my bee ant barrier posted before. Ants are a problem for beekeepers but they are also a problem for people with hummingbird feeders. The ants are aggressive seeking the sugar water solution. They'll travel along the hanger used for the feeder, once they get to the feeder they tend to enter the feeder and drown. Hummingbirds don't like ants and if the feeder has ants, the hummingbirds won't feed from the feeder.

I've made a device to automatically photograph hummingbirds. The ants were an annoyance. I tried water bowls under the the legs of my device but water evaporates, it collects bugs, and it just gets nasty. This ant barrier is a real improvement. Here's a photo at 1/2000 sec. The hummingbird will feed then back off a few inches and hover. They are easy to photograph during the hover.

Female ruby throated hummingbird in flight.

description.text:
This is a mount for Mutley's excellent flex3drive (version 3) found at https://flex3drive.com/flex3drive/.

The flex3drive allows you to keep the stepper motor mounted in the same location as stock but gives you a direct drive extruder; it does this by driving the extruder itself with a flexible cable. Excellent for all types of filament, but it is particularly good for flexible filaments.

I expect Mutley will probably eventually make a "prettier" mount, but this one works and is on my printer working quite well.

EDIT Jul 20, 2017: It came to my attention that the arms are just a tad bit shorter than is a comfortable fit, so I uploaded a new version with longer arms. I left the old one in case anyone prefers to try that one.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Honestly just about any settings that are reasonably strong will work. There is a bit of bridging needed, but if it sags a tiny bit it doesn't really matter, so I wouldn't worry about it.

Setting up the printer to use the Flex3Drive

My flex3drive is using an e3dv6 clone as the hotend. After you install it, you need to run the following gcode in order to set your printer up to use it:

NOTE: this is for using the flex3drive, not the settings for printing the mount!

M203 E35 ; Set max feedrate for extruder to 35mm/s
M201 E50 ; Set max acceleration for extruder to 50 mm/s/s
M204 R50 ; Set retract acceleration for extruder to 50 mm/s
M205 E0.1  ; Set E jerk to 0.1 mm/s
M201 X1000 Y1000  ; Set the X and Y acceleration to 1000mm/s/s
M204 T1000 ; Set the Travel acceleration to 1000mm/s/s
M92 E3800.00 ; Set the e-steps to 3800 / mm (40:1 gearing)
M500 ; Save the settings

I recommend a retract speed in your slicer of 20mm/s and keep the retract distance relatively short, I use 1mm. 5mm will tend to be noticeably slow.

Source in TinkerCad

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gHsOqjUa9Yu

title: Ikea Lack printer enclosure bracket, CHEAP AND STRONG

description.text:
Concept here is in the title: I LOVE the design from the most popular ikea lack concept... which incidentally also increases the height available to put the printer into.
I just cannot bear to go through a 5+ hours print, and 40grams of PLA... for EACH support.
Given that amount of resources, I would prefer to just saw a piece of wood to measure, or buy 90° metal brackets from the local hardware store and fashion a combo of them to raise the level...

So, enter my design. Ikea Lack gives 40cm of clearance in height, which is just enough for my geeetech i3 after I remove the top display (which I would have to remove ayway, since operating the printer on it when a lack is on top of it is pretty much impossible). I will just relocate the display outside of the enclosure, as the cables are long enough.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Anyhow, these brackets are meant to be printed laying flat (doh) so to have the highest possible resistance on flexing loads, and the raised line on top is to give a guide for the medium level between the lack on the bottom, and the one on top. Just make 8 of them and screw them to the structure.
I just hacked together a cube, a few cylinders and couple of cones inside blender.

author: ephestione

description.text: For USB power adapter (hexagonal)

This is a slide rule we designed (one piece is the outer holder and the other is the inner slider). It is blank, of course, and requires a label to be completed; our design was based on the Scientific American paper slide rule and was scaled so that the SA rule would fit if printed on 8.5x11" paper sized labels and cut out (although that's a big waste of label paper). The SA rule can be found at https://www.scientificamerican.com/media/pdf/Slide_rule.pdf but this version does not have a "cursor" as currently designed.

After printing, we found that this item will warp somewhat with the cheaper materials, and that the inner slider piece is going to fit a bit too firmly in the outer piece to actually slide, so despite our best work at adjusting the sizes, the best fix was to do a bit of sanding of the inner slider piece.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This frame is designed to mitigate a number of shortcomings of Eachine's Turbine QX70 micro quad. The overall flight performance of that micro-quad is disappointing, in particular when trying to make it work together with the NanoCam3D. However, the flight controller board is not too bad and the brushed motors are OK. The customized and 3D-printable frame was made for obstruction-free 3D-vision together with a 10° camera tilt angle, resulting in a wheel base of 80mm. Final weight of both frame and camera mount when printed in ABS: ca. 10g

title: Ball screw Remix for hypercube evolution

description.text:
Work in progress

I did not want to use cheap 8mm lead screws because I am building a tall printer.
This is for an sfu1204 or 1202 ball screw with ends machined per the drawing which costs like $4 usd in china.
Not sure if everything will line up.
It needs an upper bearing bracket designed. I might just buy an off the shelf pillow bearing and shim it to the mounting distance i need unless one of you CAD folks knows how to create one.

Biggsis corrected upper Z bracket
Scotts Lower bracket and motor mount

Elstaks Z carriage support
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2299083/#comment-1326388

7.22.17 update
I ended up ordering TR10x2 lead screws from china. So far 4 have arrived and have been bent. 2 more should come monday from a different vendor and hopefully not bent.

comments.text: How about learning about the proper use and how to mount lead screws, regular TR and ball ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: not a complete drawing.  just for checking alignment.   screw will be at least 800mm and  table approaching 10lbs.  not suited for a T8 screw.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
10 lbs ? What is that ?
There are bigger TR than TR8. A TR8 of 400mm can push 50N without buckling and no problem for a 800mm when pulling, the preferred way to use lead screw. With ball screw, your table will fall on its own weight when the power is turned off. Anyway, if the ball screw is cheap, try it. A big FFM printer poses a lot more challenges than just the lead screw.
comments.author: warham

comments.text:
16x16 mic 6 plate is around 8 lbs, add heater and the rest of the carriage.
Yes, the chinese ball screws in insanely cheap around $30 shipped and $2 for custom end machining.
From what I have seen of the folgertech ft5 the table drops from gravity with the T8 as well.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I've just ordered parts to build mine. I've ordered 420x420 (ordered at 16 9/16" square) mic6 cast alu. It's 1/4" thick and 6.9lbs (3100g).
I'm wondering if mine will fall on it's own.

description.text:
I really like tamel55's Small Spool, but I needed to load a full pound of nylon onto a spool, and the small spool was too small. I used Slic3R and 3D Builder to slice off the male and female parts of the spool halves in the original thing stl files, and fused them to make a male/female spool extension.

You just print it and thread the coupler extension in between the halves, and viola', the spool is now twice as big!

description.text:
I wanted a way to get a trigger from the Dot as soon as the Activation word is said before the rest of any command.

I then use the trigger to turn down volume / mute of any external device so that the rest of the command is recognised more accurately. I find that having TV on normally means I have to say commands quite loudly to make them reliable. The activation word (Alexa) is normally picked up more easily.

The method I use is to use a Light dependent resistor picking up part of the Dot LED ring which lights up as soon as the activation is spoken. This is fed into my Infra Red blaster which Alexa also controls, The LDR can be used to pull down a pin with a high value pull up (e.g. 20K) or it can be passed through a single stage FET (A03400) buffer to give a more definite switch over. (E.g. LDR from 3.3V to gate, gate to 0V via 10K, source to 0V, drain to input pin and 4.7K load resistor to 3.3V).

So Activation causes mute, command is spoken and system is unmuted at the completion of the command when light goes off.

My esp8266 ir blaster code is at https://github.com/roberttidey/IRBlasterWeb

The bracket here takes a GS55 LDR resistor to make it easier to put onto the Dot using a bit of tape to hold it in place.

LDR is > 300KOhm with LEDs off and goes down to about 6KOhm when LEds come on.

V2 bracket design has a slightly different shape with wider wings to cut down any stray light getting in and keeping dark current low.

Ormerod

As this is a small item with a small layer time it is quite a good idea to print 2 or 3 together to give time for the plastic to soldify between each layer

These parts are intended to be used together to allow an OWI robot arm to grip a paint brush. The brush attachment ensures that the paint brush does not become displaced during use. A cap goes on each end of one body piece. The paint brush fits through the hole in the middle.

The cavas platform is intended to elevate the canvas which should be a piece of paper. This gives the robot greater reach and coverage.

The code for the OWI robot arm is for the arduino MEGA 2560. Potentiometers must be placed on each joint and the pot values must be replaced with pot values specific to your robot.

Our battery holder is made for a bread board it can hold four batteries. We designed our bay holder on tinkercad.This batter holder was made for first graders that are having trouble holding the battery.

A tool holder for 3D printer tools. (A one-day project went out of control, lol.). In order for mini pliers hang on the hangers, they have to be either leaf springs http://amzn.to/1e7Mh0N or coil springs http://amzn.to/1hGM0TX . The hangers are friction fit, trays need to be super glued. I recommend use gel super glue http://amzn.to/1kR6BJY, instead of instant super glue.

It was printed in ABS with 0.35 mm nozzle. My printer prints extra 0.25 mm materials; that means a 10 x 10 x10 mm cube would come out as a 10.5 x 10.5 x 10.5 mm cube. Friction fit parts were made with this tolerance.   
The Hangers are friction fitted to the main body, so do a test print of a hanger and a body together in one print job. Stop the print job after the hanger is done. Then see if they fit correctly. If they don't, then cut off back beam of the hanger and glue the hangers in place.  
The main body is a large and tall part. It's best to print it by itself with a generous skirt to prevent its corners from lifting up. Also calibrate bed level before printing it.   
The Right and Left Trays (in the center) come in four sizes, 15, 25, 60 and 90 mm in depth. Pick the size that fits your needs.  
Top Plate is an aesthetic part, you can skip it. Hanger End Cap is also optional, it caps one section of the hanger; so it can be use as a tray.

description.text:
Dummy knife, ideal for airsoft or martial arts. I also uploaded the solidworks model so you can change the name, there's also a version with no name on it.
During an airsoft game I made a kill the wood throwing this knife, it was absolutely epic, you really should print this just in case you have the chance to use it.

A 305mm or more axis is required for this print

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 or even more

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Keeping the infill and shells low will actually make it very flexible even with PLA.

description.text:
I really liked the dock shelf that boydievonboyd created to get my dock up off of the desk but it was a bit too shallow as the hinges on the back of the dock stick out; it did not fit without scaling the entire model up to about 104%. I designed this one to be a little deeper, made the cable management hole larger to allow installing the HDMI cable after mounting the shelf, and added a version with pegs to hang JoyCon straps from.

If printing the version with pegs, place supports under the pegs or they will have issues. I use Simplify3D so I just manually placed supports under them.

Disclaimer: If you use this model I am not responsible for any damage that may occur to your Nintendo Switch or accessories. Because the back plate and the bottom of the shelf are only secured by fused plastic, it is possible for the shelf to snap. Use this at your own risk!

title: Heavy Fidget Spinner - 160gram Tungsten Rotor V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yet another fidget spinner from me!
Again, this one uses the 40gram tungsten golf weights for the rotor, and I've also used a Zirconium Ceramic bearing as I find they give a good spin time..

The centre mushrooms are all available in my other spinner uploads, and these are joined using a M3 x 16mm screw.. You'll need to tap the lower half to get the screw in, or you can just use brute force!

Printed in PET-G as usual, 100% fill, 1.2mm wall and top n bottom...
258C extruder, 55C bed
Bed used white decorators tape and a smear of Prit Stick...

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or 0.1mm

Infill:

100% for strength...

Notes:

Shout if you need any info re the weights or bearings or settings etc!!

comments.text:
Hey! Where can you find these weights? are they available online, I'm not familiar with this style.
Thanks.
comments.author: mikethebomber

comments.text:

Have a look here : http://goo.gl/L0QZLR

description.text: As already stated this is a model of a RT-10 Solid Fuel Booster from the game Kerbal Space Program. All the relevant detail that was in the ingame model should be in this model. The dimensions used were just rough just to get the proportion right so the model is roughly 42mm Dia x 180mm.The idea is for this to be an ongoing thing so that I would eventually have a mass of parts from the game for everyone to build and print any ship configuration desired by just drag and dropping the parts in an assembly. So keep checking my page for any future parts.

Scale the model to whatever size you wish before printing due to the model being oversized for ease of modeling.
If model is not in the correct orientation just set to print whatever way you want.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports would be required for the port openings in the case. This prevents the case from warping while printing.

description.text:
Case for the emonpi project
https://github.com/openenergymonitor/emonpi

I didn't buy the original case because I didn't like it that much. However I had no easy way to mount emonpi anywhere to protect it from the elements.

I set out to design a simple case to house emonPi that would be as small as possible and that would look good at the same time..

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Rotate the STL as needed to print flat against the bed. Recommended to use brims to keep the flat pieces from warping up at the edges.

Supports would be required for the port openings in the case. This prevents the case from warping while printing.

Just remove some of the excess material. sand or file as necessary.

Use 3 screws to affix the emon pi to the bottom layer.

Used the openly available CAD drawings of emonpi to design a case around it.

It turned out almost perfect the first try. I had to adjust the size of the lid to be a little thicker so that it would stick better to the case outline.

I came across mathgrrl and was intrigued by the rolling knot http://makerhome.blogspot.co.uk/2013/12/day-110-rocking-knot.html. I wondered if I could define it with Openscad. The challenge is to create a tube which is smooth enough and will fully render in an acceptable time. I tried a tube of simple cylinders oriented along the path but this proved desparately slow and rough. At nophead's suggestion I then moved to segments made from hull() ing successive pairs of disks or spheres. The script for spheres turned out to be not only simpler but also faster. However nophead suggested a cone instead of a disk, and with the addition of explicit render()s this provide the best performance so far. The best script is rolling-knot-hull-cone which renders the 2 degree version (180 segments) in 12 minutes on my Acer Aspire. Many thanks to mathgrrl and the helpful OpenScad community especially nop head.

comments.text: This is wonderful, thank you for doing this because I just learned a lot about OpenSCAD from reading your code!

print_settings.Notes:: Easy print.

description.text:
This lateral spool holder accepts any filament spool up o 13 mm (5.11") independent of the spool hole size. I made for my GTMax Core H4 (Brazilian Brand), but can be used in any printer with closed cabinet.

Update: Added a 10 mm shorter shaft to take advantage of the existing original shaft of GTMax Core H4.

Printer:

GTMax Core H4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20

Notes:

Easy print.

After testing multiples spool holders I decided to try a customized one. I wanted one that would accept wide, narrow rolls. Don´t need to bother about the non-standard spool holes, be practical and fixed at one side of my printer cabinet. This one was made in four parts: Bracket, shaft, spacer and cap. You will need two 602 bearings and also two thread rods of 152 mm. Print two sets. I print in two colors but can be printed any way you want.

I have made a few parts for the Spyda 500.  Body shell, Top plate with mounting points for the MultiWii/Cirrus controller board case that I have also included.  The controller case mounts to the top plate with orange ear plugs to give vibration isolation.  
I have also added a stronger DJI arm after finding that the included DJI one flexes quite a bit.  
Added a mount that can be used for APM 2.5 with my top plate.  Called  generic mount.  
Added a wall bracket to store your Spyda 500.  
Added a gimbal mount that fits on the front and will bolt to top and bottom plate with 4 m3 socket head cap screws.  The mounting holes are 2.5mm I tap them out to m3.  you will need to make two holes in top and bottom plate 34mm apart at centres.  If you use my top plate the holes are already there but the bottom plate will need them.

title: 3.0" Exhaust bend snap fabrication kit v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 3.0" of my popular 2.5" mockup kit

Finally a simple way to mock up and layout custom exhaust designs.

I designed this system similar to my header fabrication kits.
Makes exhaust system planning and layout a breeze.
Complex compound bends and miter cuts are no longer hard to figure out and test fit.

30, 45, 60, 90, and a 2"Long Straight pcs will allow you to come up with any complex bend you can think of.

They have angle reference locating notches around the outside in 45deg increments.
To make it easy for you to copy locating marks to your cut metal bends

These have a 2.5" Center line Radius. I have also added 4.5" CLR center line radius parts due to a request.

This system will not snap into my 2.5" system. I can make an adaptor if requested

Happy Building

Hello everyone, This is my entry for the "ÂFish"Â contest; had lots of fun figuring this one out. Made use of several 3D printing advantages; for example, was able to print thin enough to be flexible for the cover (and still have text on part), got a nut to thread (lightly) onto printed shaft, created three dimensional fish and grass. To be able to print the fish over and over and get constant weight for balance shows print constancy. I added simple instructions to the posted pictures. I'Âve printed and assembled the final version parts three times now and have had no fit problems. Note: something I missed in the pictures/ instructions it to use 6-32 X .50 Long Cap Head Screws (4) and 6-32 Nuts (4).
Note: some of the parts (auto generated) are shown upside down or in wrong orientation.
Note (1/27/14): created better grass, taller and gives a better look. added the .stl file for the taller grass. Enjoy, Reamo
I created an M cookie cutter for the first letter of my name (Megan).

H,i in the spirit of my Father, affectionately known as "Mr Bob" (pictured above c1960), who tried to never throw anything out that he had not repaired at least twice before, I have repaired our broken Pepper Grinder. I often wonder what he might have achieved if he had a 3-D printer in his day.

So to inspire you all to have a "Mr Bob moment" and enjoy the pleasure of reducing the landfill at our dumps, I encourage you all to try simple repairs. It is very satisfying.

Here is my repair for a the axle bridge/bearing of a "Maxwell and Williams" pepper grinder (given to us by my sister, Jenny). Printed with ABS and 70% fill, which amounted to 100%, given the size of it.

title: CO2 Laser Engraver/Cutter/CNC Machine Tube Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mounting system for a 40/50w 50mm diameter CO2 Glass Laser Tube to fit a China Blue/White Ebay 50w (really 40w) Laser CNC Engraving cutting machine.

I designed this from scratch, however I took cues from the following things so I wanted to give source idea credit:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:420853
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1263096

Neither seemed logical. Both mounted facing in which means removing the whole bracket to remove the tube.

My goals with this design:

  1. Fit my machine and tube
  2. Solidly support tube
  3. Can be installed without modifying the machine
  4. Can be installed without being an octopus
  5. Tube easily installed and removed
  6. Easy to adjust tube position at any time
  7. Use mostly common materials (preferably what I have on hand)
  8. Easy to reproduce
  9. Can be adapted for additional tube sizes (upgrades later)

I started out with notches for some plastic tubing, however the tubing I had was too stiff and I was afraid it would put too much pressure on the glass tube so I used some open cell foam instead which worked just as well. I left the notches in the ring for those who may have better tubing on hand.

The inner ring has a 54mm opening which allows for 2mm room on all sides of a 50mm tube for whatever padding/tubing you choose to employ.

You will need 6 4mm x 4.6mm heat sets: https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a351/=17jj3tx
The rest of the hardware is all cap head 4mm screws and nuts commonly available at local hardware stores.

Here is a video of the 3D:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PWiKpKNmNiA
I rendered the video with transparent materials of different colors to show how the pieces fit together.

This was designed to fit in my Blue/White China laser. I do not know if it will fit other laser machines. If you do print it and it does fit your machine, let me know so I can add the info to this description and keyword tags for others to find.

I printed mine in PETG using 3mm layer heights. However I feel ABS and PLA are also just as suitable for this print.

Here is a blog post on the install:
http://www.wolfiesden.com/diy-blog/50w-laser-tube-holder/

title: CAT5/6 RJ45 and Fused Power Switch Face Plate

description.text:
A RJ45 and fused power switch faceplate

This is a faceplate derived from roskiy's "CAT5 faceplate for RJ45 jack"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1150624
The "soluciones Imposibles" watermark on the inside of the plate has been removed to make room for the power switch

with the addition of a fused power switch pulled out of Elizabwth's "Anet A8 Power Switch (minimal material)"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2000523

the idea is to have an external power and cat jack for a printer/octopi combo inside an enclosure

There is a provided .blend file in case you need that. Personally, I think the polygon's cleaned up quite well but I'm hardly a good modeler. there are some intersecting faces left on the keystone clip of the RJ45 jack but those were there when I imported the STL and it seems to print fine so I didn;t bother cleaning them up.

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I'd personally suggest using skirt and not brim bed adhesion. The bevels on the faceplate will end up looking weird because the curve will be interrupted by the inevitable extra material from the brim. no matter how thorough you are in removing it.

The print I did have an incident involving the detachment of the fan nozzle around layer 2. so I had to stop it and clean up. however, the print was intact enough I decided to continue and it can out fine aside from some scarring of the face touching the bed.
My print can ou a bit out of square as always that first layer is key.

After importing the STL files of the reference models the faceplate was modified to have only one jack moved farther up. once the power switch model was stripped down to the faces that composed the switches holes a simple alignment and boolean difference operation fused them. After that, the 3D Print Toolbox add-on of blender helped me clean up the normals and non-manifold edges.

remixed_from.author: swholmstead
remixed_from.title: Knurled Tri-Spinner Fidget Widget / Triple Bearing Spinner

description.text:
The Fidget Spinner is the hottest toy around right now and there are a lot of files on Thingiverse for them. I tried several and was disappointed with the results. I don't like to waste three bearings so I don't like the classic design. The thing I remixed this from was good, but it was a bit thin around the bearing and was prone to breaking. I also didn't like the nuts sticking out beyond the edges. This is a remix/redesign of several tri-spinners. I find that it works really well! I hope that you will enjoy it as well.
You will also need:
1-608 Bearing (since you didn't waste money buying 4 you and afford on ceramic one)
3- 1/2" SAE nut
I recommend that you print this in ABS or PETG. These get dropped a lot and in PLA they break when they hit the floor. I also recommend that you anneal your parts after you print them as this adds a lot of strength.
https://rigid.ink/blogs/news/how-to-anneal-your-3d-prints-for-strength
If you don't print in ABS because your are scared of the fumes, don't listen to the blogs, the fumes aren't very bad, I print in ABS all day long in a closed office and I hardly notice at all.

Enjoy this thing and happy printing!

If you would like one of these and don't want to hassle with printing it, visit my shop: https://www.etsy.com/listing/517021580/nutty-fidget-spinners?ref=shop_home_active_1

Update: For those that want a large button on either side, I added that file as well.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2.0

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I recommend that you print this in ABS or PETG. PLA is too weak and brittle to stand up to the use that these things get.
I anneal these for 45 mins at 200 f. then I post process with acetone.
I used Mesh Mixer to redesign this thing

This requires no assembly. Just print in place. When printed, just pick out the small amount of support, spin the bearings, and add oil.

NOTE: This is fully made of plastic and will not spin as well as a metal ball bearing. Yet, it is still fun to fidget and spin. Also, print with a high quality and a high fill for better spinning. Be careful to use a needle-nose plyers to remove support from the bearings.

author: mildot

description.text:
Because I'm going to be producing a bunch of Halloween/Jack-o-Lantern eggs, I thought I'd go ahead and share some of the faces.
WARNING: This was created in Inkscape 0.91, which defines 1" as 90 DPI. Inkscape 0.92 defines 1" as 96 DPI, so this file will need to be adjusted accordingly.

• Start with a room temperature egg (if using raw or hard boiled egg), or a cleaned, hollowed-out egg. Or other ovoid object, that won't have the ink run when applied.
  • Load "egg" into egg-bot, and make adjustments to the egg-bot as necessary.
  • Load pen into egg-bot, and make adjustments as necessary.
  • "Prime" the pen by running a scrap of paper under the nib.
  • Assuming one is using Inkscape to print, open the Egg-bot control panel, and make any adjustments as necessary.
  • Go to Plot tab, and APPLY.

comments.author: Scalethor

description.text:
This is a dragonfly made from separate pieces for the head, body, wings, and tail sections. I used transparent filament (clear for the body/head/alternate tail sections, and blue or magenta for the colors).

These pieces were printed on a Lulzbot Taz5 using CURA to pre-process.

The proportions I used were:
Tail: 12.5 mm from base to top
Wing: 50 mm on long axis
Head: 10 mm (sitting flat on plane from bottom of head to top of eyes)
Body: 50 mm on long axis

Once the pieces are printed, use your favorite acrylic welding compound (I've been using Plastruct or Plastiweld with good results). The only tricky part is the wings - I would suggest joining the single wings into left and right pairs first, and then attaching the pairs to the body segment once they are dry. Note that I've attached the wings to the larger flat side of the body shape, to give a little more surface area to balance them.

For hanging, the trick is to wrap a piece of beading wire (or a similar light wire) around the center of the body and then attach the wire to a piece of fishing line. Otherwise, it is pretty difficult to directly tie a piece of nylon fishing line to the dragonfly and to get it to stay in place at the correct position so that the dragonfly is balanced when it is suspended.

I designed this using a combination of JavaGami polyhedron modeling software and Rhino to attach eyes to the head. Each piece is printed separately to make it possible to interchange colors and filament types, and to make it easier to print on classroom-grade 3D printers without too much frustration or reprinting if there are issues during the print.

title: Cupholder Adapter for Yeti Lowball -to- German Car

description.text:
This will hold a Yeti Lowball, and fit into a small (too small for the Yeti!) cupholder common on many German auto makes.

*** Update - 13 July 2017: Shrinkage! My cupholder sits in a hot car all day. As such, it did indeed shrink and my Yeti no longer fits well. My recommendation is to scale up the print accordingly. If using PLA, scale up the model by 5%. Refer to this article on annealing, which is a good approximation for sitting in a hot car on 100F sunny days. https://rigid.ink/blogs/news/how-to-anneal-your-3d-prints-for-strength

Features:

  • Fits a Yeti Lowball
  • Has a horizontal offset to allow positioning options that avoid overhanging obstructions, such as the dashboard.
  • There is a pocket to hold a phone (up to an iphone 7 plus)
  • There is a coin chamber in the bottom, which doubles as a counter balance to lower the CG in the event that the cupholder is too loose.
  • The fit into a BMW cupholder is nicely snug.
  • Optional BMW logo.
  • Dim: 9.5cm wide, 12.7cm deep, 16.3cm high.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 um

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This took 15+ hours to print. I used PLA. My Prusa has a PEI surface, and I applied a little bit of glue stick to the PEI.

The logo version of the model has an error which causes the interior surface immediately behind the logo badge to print with an unintended indent that is about 1 cm in diameter. This defect does not impact the functionality or the outward appearance. This defect does not show up in the STL renderings, but the slicer (I used Slic3r) does reveal it.

I edited the BMW logo model built by https://grabcad.com/latheesh.v.m.villa-1 at https://grabcad.com/library/bmw-logo-3d-model-not-decal-1

title: Black Widow Dual Power Supply Control Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This Control Box is a simple mod on the Black Widow control box that uses exiting Black Widow Control box parts of the Sides and the Smoked Clear Top panel.

As this is a first run edition there may be some modifications you need to make to have it work for you.

At this time I added 8 larger 4mm hex cap screws than the ones that came with the Black Widow Control box. If you have assembled the Black Widow Control box adding these parts will not be an issue.

This is a work in progress, I currently have my box up and running but will be making modifications over the summer to streamline assembly and wire management. This is a first generation control box mod with potential for other upgrades.

The Side panels in the pic above are my own custom panels. If you would like to have your side panels customized to your own design please contact me via messages here and I can work out a special .stl for your design. Until I can work out how to use the design your own using my baseline then it can be done here on Thingiverse.

If you like the design and Print it please post your makes. I like seeing what others have done also pop a like as that helps others find this.

Good Luck and message if you have any questions or possible needs. I will get back to you each evening when I get home from work.

Black Widow

No

Yes

30%

Notes:

The Top and bottom Panel Take up 90% of the bed width on the Black Widow. For best results and no extruder stopping issues be sure to place your prints to the left most side of the bed.
The Design is a derivative of the original Black Widow Control Box the parts should interface with the existing side panels and smoke clear top panel.

title: Robo 3D R1+ Dual Extrusion One Hotend

description.text:
This is my first attempt at dual extrusion on my Robo3D R1+. I took the wade extruder file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:729956, and modified it to fit the R1+ quick release hotend, as well as to include a separate filament path with a y-junction inside the part. I'm hoping to make a similar setup to the prometheus dual extrusion system (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/811909269/the-prometheus-system-intuitive-multi-filament-3d).

The whole assembly is only a half inch taller than the original part, and the second filament path entrance can be found between the two holes in the top of the part. Once I can figure out how to add a 6th stepper motor to my RAMPS board for the R1+, I will update this page with a tutorial explaining how to do this upgrade. If you have any suggestions regarding the addition of a 6th stepper motor to the R1+, please comment here and let me know.

UPDATE: I was able to install a new board and stepper motor to drive the second strand of filament. However, the direct drive extruder I ordered to feed the second filament into the y-junction and hotend is not powerful enough to do so without jamming, and the all-metal construction of the stock hexagon hotend certainly does not help the filament flow smoothly after repeated retractions. Once I am able to solve these problems, I will post a full build tutorial and review. It may require me to replace the hotend with another that uses a PTFE tube, something that I am hesitant to do because I do not want to lose my ability to print with higher temperature filaments. I will also see about replacing the second extruder assembly with a wade style extruder in order to increase its torque.

comments.text: Solved... https://www.prusaprinters.org/original-prusa-i3-mk2-multi-material-upgrade-release/ rather than finding a ramps board with an expansion set, you can basically use a splitter (stepper multiplex board) for multiple extruders on the one extrusion output. Not sure what would have to be modified in the Firmware, Gcode or Slicer but sounds like a fun adventure. Definitely look forward to someone testing this on a Robo.
comments.author: Scottyrtobin

comments.text: Any progress on the Prometheus system upgrade. I am also attempting to make a system like this that will feed directly into the Robo's default extruder. I found that prusa printers have a similar setup https://www.prusaprinters.org/original-prusa-i3-mk2-multi-material-upgrade-release/ . Not sure if the R1+ has enough openings for the extra stepper motors but I will look soon. Let me know if you have any progress.

description.text:
UPDATE 15JUL2017: I redesigned the spinner so it prints cleaner now. The blades are uniform thickness so your slicer hopefully won't start and stop mid blade

I designed this to resemble the "Fan" section of a jet turbine engine. Simply blowing on it will spin it.

The fan is directional. Due to the curve of the blades, blowing on it from one side vs the other will make it spin much faster. Just holding it to the air vent in your car with the blower on high will spin it a lot. You can easily see the speed difference depending on the direction. If you print this the way it's facing in the STL, the side that is facing up while on the build plate, is the side that you should direct the air, to make it spin the fastest.

Use my Spinner Press to help insert the bearings. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275122

comments.author: Gophy

comments.text: ok thanks, i'll try it anyways :)
comments.author: mistertech

comments.text: It could technically fly! The Problem is, that the "propeller" just spins in one direction. That will cause an effect which lets the spinner fly to the the side! I don't know the exact name, because i'm a german ;) In Germany we call it "Drall" and Google Translate says it is called "twist" in english. Back to topic... This effect is prevented in airplanes byplacing the motor with a slope of 3 degrees in the opposite direction in which the prop is spinning, or (at twin-motor-Airplanes) by letting the two props spin in two different directions.This spinner has neither of those two importnat properties, so i would'nt fly properly. I hope, that i helped you!
